headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:

I'd like to welcome you to our investor call and webcast. As the operator mentioned, the subject of today's call is ASML's 2009 fourth quarter and annual results. Co-hosting today's call from our head quarters in Veldhoven, the Netherlands are Mr. Eric Meurice, ASML's CEO and Mr. Peter Wennink ASML's CFO.
At this time, I’d like to draw your attention to the Safe Harbor Statement contained in today's press release and in our fourth quarter results presentation, both of which you may find on our website at www.asml.com. Now, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Meurice, for a brief introduction. Eric?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Thank you, Craig. Good afternoon and good morning, thank you for attending our Q4, 2009 results conference call. Peter and I would like to provide a new review and some comments earlier in the quarter. And as usual Peter will start with a review of the Q4 financial performance, with added comment on the short term outlook. I will complete the introduction with some further details on our current situation, as we close out 2009 and head into 2010. Following the introduction, we would open up for questions. So Peter, please?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. As Eric mentioned, I would like to take a moment to share some observations on the events of the last quarter, as-well-as some details on our fourth quarter results. We will start with that. Our fourth quarter sales were EUR 581 million this was slightly higher than our sales guidance for the quarter. We shipped a total of 25 systems, 19 of which were new. New system ASP was EUR 19.7 million versus EUR 22.4 million in the third quarter, which indicates a substantial blend of emerging and non-emerging tools, we shipped 11 emerging tools and 14 non-emerging tools. Reflecting an increased demand from our Foundry customers for capacity related tools. 
The average selling price of new and used systems combined was EUR 17.3 million and was therefore also lower than in the third quarter. Our service and field option sales were high at close to EUR 150 million, this was primarily driven by productivity upgrades. Such upgrades are not unusual as customers look for incremental capacity when a rise in their product demand suddenly becomes evident. 
And the company fourth quarter gross margin was 38% versus 34.4% in the third quarter. This reflects an improved coverage of our fixed manufacturing cost, cost reductions and stronger service and field option sales later generally carrying high gross margins
We have continued our focus on R&D with a spent of 150 million in the fourth quarter, which was by the way the same as our spent in Q3. And SG&A came in at 37 million which is about the same as what we had in Q3.
As a result of the afore mentioned, operating income improved from 7% in the third quarter to around 12% in Q4. And last quarter of the year, we generated EUR 19 million in net cash. We are glad we were able to close our 2009 with a cash balance comfortably over EUR 1 billion.
Q4 net bookings were strong at 40 systems, value at EUR 956 million, net immersion bookings were at 25 systems, 23 were new and 2 are used, and that this demonstrates a continued focus on technology investments driven again by the DRAM and foundry market segments with fresh investments just beginning to emerge.
In addition we sold 12 new KrF bookings, indicating a continued need for more non-critical systems and support of the leading edge production ramp of our foundry customers.
Fourth quarter bookings pushed our backlog to EUR 1.85 billion containing 69 systems at DRAM that being the highest level of the backlog in 10 quarters.
We are highlighting is the fact that there are 51 immersion systems in our backlog, 17 of which are our newest immersion product the NXT:1950.
As for the outlook, we continue to increase factory production capacity in order to meet the growing demand, as indicated by our fourth quarter and the anticipated first quarter bookings. However, due to the fact that the normal production lead time for our more complex and new leading edge products is still fairly low, we will not be able to completely satisfy all demand in the desired delivery time. As a result some first quarter delivery requests will be shipped early Q2, but now our ramp up capability would have accelerated. And as a result, we expect the first quarter sales to be about EUR 700 million, with the second quarter coming in around to EUR 950 million. 
Gross margin in the first quarter is expected to be about 40%, R&D expenses are expected to be EUR 120 million and SG&A 40 million. Forward furthermore we expect orders in the first quarter to be at approximately the same level as the fourth quarter of 2009, mainly driven by memory customer and foundry customers again.
And finally in respect of 2009, ASML will submit the proposal to the 2010 General meeting with shareholders to declare an unchanged dividend of $0.20 per share.
And now I'd like to turn it the call to Eric who will give us some more views on the upcoming quarters.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter. So we close the year as planned with recovering sales and the strong Q4 systems booking of EUR 956 million, confirming the semi-conductor segment up turn. This up turn is currently mainly driven by technology buys from the DRAM sector by a fairly modest technology set of buy from flash sector and capacity buys by the first [dual] foundry at 40 and 45 nanometer. We believe that we will see a continued high level of booking for the beginning of the year. There certain numbers of engines of growth are contributing to this. First the view top of 40 nanometer DRAM capacity we had continue well into their [H2] 2010. As the second batch of DRAM players will start ramping then. 
Second, the long awaited 30 nanometer flash RAM and 20 Nanometer development flash will also start contributing more heavily in Q3, 2010. Third, we expect structural foundry built in [H2] including the first year, but also the second year customers. 
With our current 2010 shipments run rate, we have calculated that the [leasable installed] base will support semiconductor unit capacity increase of only 12% in 2010 versus 2009. Upside to this semiconductor unit gross number, as discussed by most industry analyst at this very time could justify improved lithography shipment run rates during the year. In other terms, the structural capacity catch up that we are seeing today, the technology base and the potential capacity GAAP to demand [grows] support at minimum and the current litho shipment run rate, while certainly not contributing any surplus capacity. 
With this demand ramp as a background, we are continuing to focus our product development on product development and new product introductions. We have now converted all our mid range TWINSCANS to an upgraded platform with a higher throughput better overlay and better CD uniformity. We are also ramping our new NXT platform, with state of the art performance. We are deploying our holistic lithography product suite and we continue development of the UV technology. Regarding the NXT our new platform, we now have installed base of the five systems and a backlog of 17 systems 11 in the memory sector, 5 in the IDM sector and one in the foundry sector. Customers if they are ramping up these machinery NXTs in to volume production Q2 2010.
Our holistic lithography product suite including the customer accepted software solutions, producing higher process yields is being further enhanced by FlexRay our flexible illumination system and our Yield star, Standalone and Inline metrology systems. These hardware when (inaudible) with a software of the suite provides even better scanner performance and greater factory process control. 
Regarding EUV technology, we are making good system integration progress that along with a continued source performance development allows us to confirm our ability to ship the first pre-production systems in the second half of 2010 systems for which we plan to close the fix order very soon. We believe that the renewed industry interest for product and technology transitions that we are seeing today. In conjunction with ASML's stronger position mainly due to improved cost structure, that also differentiated and diverse products has positioned ASML very well for its next significant growth opportunity.
So, on this summary I would like to leave it to you to ask Peter and I questions.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Good afternoon its (inaudible), thanks for taking my question. I'd just like to ask a question on the flash memory market and more specifically on SSD's just like some of your opinion on basically the impacts of that technology on your revenues if I’m correct the adoption of SSD is quiet modest at this point for Netbooks and Notebooks probably in the low single digit levels, so what I’m wondering is, is SSD's adoption in Notebooks and Netbooks were to reach something like 10%, what would be the impact in your view on demand following that we'll see equipment and related to that what sort of technology would be required when you talk to your customers to get to the sort of break, sort of inflection point on pricing to re-drive adoption of SSD's?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Very good question, because SSD is a very large driver, clearly there has been a bit of a disappoint in some ways as SSD has remained in the areas of I would say 3, 4, 5% mount rate in the PC world, to get to about 10% you would have to have about 1 billion to 1.5 billion of lithography equipment. The customers I think have started to indicate to us that the amount rate is probably going to increase due to two things. One, they are improving the drivers with the software drivers which I think is more or less related to Windows 7. I understand that it is not yet perfect but I understand its improving and therefore will increase the speed of adoption. 
In addition it is true that there is a sort of new agreement that SSD cost target will be so much more supported by 20 nanometer which is the current development being put in place by the first year. So in other terms, SSD didn’t really contribute anything at this moment into billings and into bookings and we expect this to be one of the upside opportunities of the second half of 2010 and into significantly into 2011 and '12.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Great and in your view, when Google announced that you know their Chrome operating system would be only supported by SSDs, I mean do you think that could kick start the market or do you think that it’s a bit further out?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: No it is certainly another obvious position that says the world will probably get beyond 10%. I think that’s a message that the whole industry is expecting, that the key question is an economic question really is exactly when do you have an inflection point and an acceleration point and to that I'm not a specialist of the industry so I cannot really answer to you. But clearly, we expect to beyond 10% and we look forward to say 2% to 3% market share 2% to 3% amount rate on that correspond to about 1 billion of lithography. So we feel this is a significant driver of the business and we feel good that it will last next five years or so.

componenttext:
You know it is impossible for us to be specific on customers who we are trying to brush and answer that makes sense for you and your modeling. Yes Japan is clearly at this moment DRAM vendor, a Flash vendor and a very, very, very small market. For the rest as you know the business of logic is not booming at all at this moment in Japan. So, in the DRAM sector there is a definitely split business between Japan and Taiwan in terms of Elpida, and we are happy as you know to have won their confidence I think that is public and as you know they have announced themselves that they are ramping their production as of Q1. So this production is going to be split between Taiwan and Japan. The Flash environment in general as we said has been I would not say disappointed, but small and this is because it is true that the whole industry have built up significant over capacity which took 2009 to be digested and it is highly possible that Toshiba in fact it is clearly the case of Toshiba. 
So, we have also said that the flash business is going to comeback. It was a revenge driven by the applications we talked about, plus additional needs in mobile phones and additional needs in servers and this is starting to built up momentum as of Q2 and that will increase our business in Japan.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: And then on the supply constraints. It seems that you now at about 1100 flexible labor. I think you were at 1,700 in 2008. So, my question really is the supply bottleneck, is that more within ASML or is it more within the supply chain?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: No it is definitively the supply chain although we thank our suppliers for their effort because in reality the constrains is because we have converted all our products to the new products in the mid-range used to be called the XT3 versions that is internal code. It is now an XT4 version, the new machine called the NXT. So you're talking about having to rebuild from scratch from zero a complete supply chain which usually would take between one year or nine months at least to be setup inclusive their own CapEx etcetera, etcetera. So this is the main constraints. Our business is one of integration where testing is more important and yes it is easier for us to build up temporary workers or using some of our engineers to do more. So we definitively are far from being the limits, the limit is because we are moving up all those new products and it takes time to build up the pipeline.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Hi Satya Kumar from Credit Suisse, quick question on your orders from memory. I presume obviously most of these orders are coming from DRAM. How much of these orders are from technology shrinks versus capacity and at this point, do you have a sense of what portion of the installed base in DRAM has already placed orders to shrink now that’s near backlog in Q4.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: First question is easier to answer, in DRAM bookings that we got, 100% is technology transition. In fact this is one of the things we have discovered. It seems that now the customers have this capability of using all the installed base in the, what we call the non-critical layers of the new technology and therefore the only thing they need is the critical layers and that’s why they only buy the latest machine which obviously be immersion, so in DRAM clearly 100% is an immersion deal, critical layers and non critical are basically installed base. Regarding percentages of what remains to be booked by the guys who have already started, I would say we are at 50% of the first tier and we are low on the second tier.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: If I look at, I mean continuation on the DRAM again, if I look at your 2009 shipments to memory an aggregate that was left on the fourth of the shipments to be factor in 2007 peak year. Obviously DRAM supply growth was constrained and clearly you were guiding the low consensus for Q1, one of your customers this morning actually lowered supply growth projections for 2010 because of the lack of equipment availability, supposing we get another 40% or 50% demand growth for DRAM in 2011, would we need to start to see capacity orders from DRAM to meet that demand, because you are sort of using up all the shrink spent this year?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
In fact, first of all its very difficult to explain why would a supply customer will be reducing or increasing its output may be because it’s a need to driven but it maybe other reasons for that but clearly at this moment everybody is trying to ramp as fast as possible in my opinion I think the biggest issue that they will have is that they also have to ramp new technologies and processes is not only CapEx its, we do not know about  the yield, we do not know about the complexity of making it work, so you are going to have full period of 6 to 9 months tons of difficulties in this segment of ramping to demand so that in turn will create potential need for additional bookings because some of the guys who will have more difficulty to hit the customers needs, the customers will go for the competitors.
So you are going to potentially have in fact an acceleration of bookings on some areas to try to win the places where they cannot deliver. Our own constraints is, yes, we are indeed putting constraints on our customer at this moment because you start from scratch and at the moment in this industry where the customers come and say I need to have delivery in three months and we all know the theoretical returns ’09, so there is obviously some haggling about who is right/wrong etcetera and the terms we are creating some constraint but at this moment I would not consider this constraints are a life threatening to anybody nor stopping you to buy any nice end products.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Sorry I guess the question was in 2011 I understand that 2010 technology shrink part of it, but in 2011 if you again get demand growth?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: The node today in DRAM is [40 nano] and in 2011 there is going to be another node in fact we are at this moment reviewing the requirements for the new nodes and it seems that the DRAM industry is putting itself on a one year type lead-time for new nodes from a original 18 months. So, there is something at this moment which is happening for 2011 a new sector of technology.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: There is not clear at whether that the [shrink] will better be satisfied the [bit] growth demand in 2011, there is notification we need new [fabs] and that’s what you were looking for and that’s unclear right now, that really depends on the [bit] growth numbers that we should try to find out how much debt could be for 2011. Now those numbers have been going up, the industry unless have over last 2-3 months have actually up their forecast for [bit] growth and we are, currently trying to figure out what that would mean in terms of real additional capacity in terms of new fabs, where else that’s not clear.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: I just had a question on the competitive position of the NXT, versus Nikon mainly because of the lot of noise in the market associated with some customers trying out the new Nikon tool etcetera. How you see your positioning in terms of what you shift as well as what you have in terms of order from the major customers and I have one follow-up.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
So, definitely our competitor is very valid competitor working on value generation so our competition is clearly on the capabilities, on the performance of the machine. At this moment most of us are running our machines, our software NXT and Nikon the 620 to try to meet their customer's requirements. We think that with five installed base and a backlog of 17 was certain numbers of committed production we have proven to the customer that we've reached the level of performance that fits the needs. We understand that our competitor will continue improving and improving and improving their machine this look very, very similar to us to the competition that started two years ago under (inaudible) and our XT, at the time we were fighting or targeting different specification, today is about the same situation the specification is basically the customer specification so we have to try to make it. 
It will have to be proven who can make it which are the products which are at the end of the day have more extendibility, more capability and better cost of ownership. We feel comfortable about that, that race because we are still using a TWINSCAN concept which allows machine to be measuring its wafers while its exposing, which allows in fact you to decide how much you want to measure, which allow you to decide to in fact obtain an extremely good performance of chip presumption. Our competitor is using still a serial method by which you measure and then you expose by doing this it is logical to understand that if you measure a lot to achieve very good exposure performance then it takes time and then the lends waits until you can expose.
So it has a lowest throughput and potentially how your cost will furnish it. So, we are comfortable that our concept is still different than our competitors and allow us to think that what we achieved when we introduced TWINSCAN in 2000 will be projected in the next decade, because we are still using differentiated architecture.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Eric. Just one question Peter on the margin, I mean in the previous calls we’ve talked about I mean hitting and going towards the 30% margin as to be. How we've been looking at gross margin then I mean given EUR 950 million in order in take approximately in the fourth quarter, by the fourth quarter of this year I mean possibly you could have revenues not of a EUR 1.05 billion or so. So I mean if you did your numbers sitting today I mean what would be we be looking at gross margins at that sort of revenue level?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Well, I think clearly you understand, I am not going to give you any guidance on the fourth quarter gross margins. But to give you an indication, we said drivers for the gross margin development were adjustments in the cost structure as of that of product mix and especially focused on those products that will enhance the value of our tools, i.e. holistic litho products which we are making progress with also in terms of shipments and ordering. That will find its way partially through lets say a field service and sales, but also in the value that we can contribute to the tool. 
Those are the elements next to the higher volume which will give us a better [load] of the fixed cost of which we said also last year that our target is to go if we start moving towards our focus on 5 billion, that we won’t have our target of 45% gross margin. Now clearly we're not going to be there from one quarter to the others going to be a trajectory, that’s going to take a bit of time, but when you talk about sales level should just indicate if clearly the gross margin will be definitely significantly over 40%. It would be heading towards our target, whether we would be there in the fourth quarter is too early to say, but that’s definitely what our target is and we should be heading in that right direction.
What that would mean for the operation margin, you were referring to, clearly we said also in the previous calls that that could be heading towards the 30% mark and that is easy if you take let’s say the 5 billion at 45%, then you subtract our R&D cost and our SG&A cost you can make that calculation easily.
So clearly the gross margin and the operating margin trajectory is quite clear to us and the higher levels of sales to level that you just mentioned, that would be help.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Tim Arcuri. Please state your company name followed by your question.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Citigroup, thanks. Two things, first of all if I take your June quarter shipment which you're actually guiding to and I assume that litho is going to be roughly 25% of wafer fab equipment which is up fairly sizably versus what it's in the last couple of years. So I'm sort of building in some share gain there for litho, it implies that the industry is going to spend about 50 billion, so that’s sort of at a 50 billion CapEx run rate which is odd because all the companies, if you add up where all the companies are sort of guiding CapEx to, it’s more like 35 or 37 billion. So I'm kind of wondering, is it that people are forward buying lithography or is it that the companies just aren’t sort of coming clean with how much money that they are going to spend this year? And then I had a follow up next.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Well, definitely I think historically, litho have been forward bought because the lead time is enormous when that was signed and secondly it takes also a very significant timing to qualify your litho tools, so the wafers out takes a long time, so yes there is a timing issue. 
Secondly, we cannot really comment on your 25% share of litho to the total CapEx in particular, on the quarter. You are now talking about not only where the customers have been able to only buy equipments which help them on the critical layers and using their install base for non critical, even for litho, it’s kind of new. We used to have a more balanced situation by which a customer would come and say, I've got the new fab to make the fab work, I need three normal line would be 3 or 4 immersion, 5 to 10 KrF and 5 to 10 i-line and we would take an order for that, that was the original way of doing business about 2 to 3 years ago.
We haven’t done that for 2 to 3 years, we are only shipping the leading-edge. So it may be that you ratios have to be re-filled completely in view of this model. I can’t really help  you on this one because you are now, having talked to Applied Materials, KLA et cetera, but for us we are certain that the guidance that we've given correspond to spots in those fabs and if we were not to ship, the customers will definitely not be able to build even the same amount of wafers of the new products than they even had in 2009 which would be impossible.
So in another terms, you can question whether the run rate we lost more than four quarters, but you cannot question that the run rate will not last for two quarters. Secondly I think you should look at another ratio if you wanted to do microeconomic ratio, you should take the diffusion rate, litho CapEx divided by sales of semiconductors. You will see an interesting curve, you will see that the curve was hovering around 3% for a long time and then it went up in 2007 when the DRAM business got crazy and it went from 3% to say 3.2-3.3 and then since 2007, that ratio is down.
Last year it was 1.5% and this year it maybe less than two or at 2% if some of the analyst are correct. So you are talking about significant number, yes 950 million in the quarter but if you divide this by the total expectation of silicon revenue, you are going to be surprised that we are much lower than historical curves.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext: Okay, the GAAP is just so significant that it just sort of indicates that maybe there is going to be a follow up in bookings later on this year, but as a follow up it seems like the weaker shipments in March came out of nowhere a bit and I am little surprised because if it’s related to the technology platform, it seems like you would have known about that before, so I am sort of wondering whether there were something that occurred between your meetings with folks during the quarter and now that [cut] sort of came out of nowhere that lead your -- you to be more shipping constraint in March.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttext:
Yes and no, the discussion is for the fourth quarter where customers have been, do you want XTs or do you want NXTs? When you usually come up with this question, the customers always want NXTs and of course then you get yourself into a mode and say well an NXT has a nine-months lead time and XT has a six months lead time. And then you have to compromise this because of course the customer want an NXT because it has supposedly a longer lead time, a longer lifetime with more extensibilities. headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Thank you, Eric, and welcome to everyone. As Eric mentioned, I would like to take a moment to share some observations on the events of last quarter, as well as some details on our first quarter results. First quarter sales came in at EUR 742 million versus EUR 581 million in the fourth quarter of last year, which was well within the range of our guidance. We shipped a total of 34 systems, 23 of which were new. Our new system ASP of EUR 25.8 million is a significant increase from the EUR 19.7 million in Q4. And it indicates a shift back to richer mix of immersion tools. The mix of the prior quarter was impacted by the demand from foundries for capacity-related tools. Our service and field option sales came in at EUR 110 million, which can be considered normal given our current business commissions. The company's first quarter gross margin was 40.3% versus 38% in Q4. And this reflects an improved coverage of our fixed manufacturing costs and cost reductions. We continued our focus on R&D with a spend of EUR 120 million in the first quarter. SG&A came in at EUR 41 million, slightly higher than Q4 but that's in support of the growing level of sales through the course of 2010.  On higher sales and improved gross margin in the first quarter, operating income improved to 18.5% from 11.8% in Q4. In the first quarter, despite the working capital ramp, we generated EUR 50 million in net cash. With that, we again maintained a cash balance comfortably over EUR 1 billion.  The first quarter net bookings met our expectations at 50 systems valued just over EUR 1 billion. Net immersion bookings of 24 systems demonstrated a continued focus on technology investments, driven again by DRAM and the Foundry market segments. But in addition, we saw KrF bookings of 17 systems, indicating a continued need for more non-critical systems in support of the leading edge production ramp, and is mainly in the non-memory applications. First quarter bookings pushed our backlog to over EUR 2 billion, containing 85 systems, which is by the way, the highest backlog value in our history. Worth highlighting also is the fact that there are 58 immersion systems in the backlog, 28 of which are our newest immersion product, the TWINSCAN NXT 1950. As for our outlook, we continued to increase  factory production capacity in order to meet the growing demand as indicated by our Q4 and Q1 bookings and our Q2 bookings guidance. The latter, we expect, again, to be at a level that is approximately the same as we saw in Q1. With this level of bookings and the ramp up of our production capability, we've clearly created the potential to record a top line revenue number for 2010 that will exceed the previous peak revenue of the year 2007. For the second quarter of 2010, we expect net sales to be about EUR 1 billion. Gross margin for the second quarter is expected to be around 42%. R&D expected to be around EUR 125 million, and SG&A around EUR 42 million. With that brief summary, I would like to turn back over to Eric for more on our view of the coming quarters. Eric?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Thank you, Peter. So as I said, Q1 sales and bookings came in as planned with high bookings expected to continue also into Q2, giving us added confidence in a prolonged recovery of the semiconductor industry. Such an upturn can last two to three years if one replicates a profile of historical cycles. Of course, our challenge is to remain cautious as to any signs which may signal a correction to this trend. But the two main drivers, IC unit demand and technology conversion CapEx requirements currently remain in positive territory. In fact, I would say IC unit demand is in positive territory and technology conversion CapEx requirement is in very, very positive territory. Indeed, the large first half revenues continue to be driven by technology buys from the early adopters in the DRAM market segment, currently converting capacity from the 65 or 55 nanometer products to 40 nanometer node. And in the Foundry segment building up at this moment, there are 40 nanometer capacity. The second half of the year, we'll see this trend continue, in particular, as the second tier vendors are ramping in those same segment, with also initial demand for 30-nanometer NAND Flash capacity starting. This NAND Flash has been fairly weak so far. Our 2010 revenues could therefore exceed our previous EUR 3.8 billion peak annual revenues achieved in 2007. Demand for IC units is still forecasted to be robust, as up to 15% above 2009. And importantly, the technology transitions that we discussed are requiring a significant increase of immersion lithography layers. That is the numbers of lithography passes per wafer processed using these new immersion lithography systems. Immersion layers will respectively double for the DRAM and Logic products, and increase by about 40% or more for the NAND product. Considering that there was a reduction of almost 20% of the memory capacity in the form of 200 mm fab, which were retired in 2008 and 2009. We are comforted that the significant and prolonged lithography tool delivery level is absolutely necessary, without creating overcapacity in the industry. To enable these technically aggressive node transitions, we have now shift nine NXT 1950, which is our most advanced TWINSCAN dual-stage scanner, having proven critical dimension emerging uniformity well below 1 nanometer, and overlay of less than 2 nanometers, which is industry-leading performance, of course. At the end of Q1, we had 28 NXT systems in backlog, 22 in memory and 64 IBM's Logic. We expect to ship 11 of those 28 in the second quarter. And we'll still grow our NXT backlog in the second quarter. On the technology front, as immersion processes are extended by the use of complex double patterning techniques, we are deploying holistic lithography project suite, which enables the widening of critical process windows in within. And allows for tighter process control in the fab on the other. This capability further significantly differentiates our TWINSCAN immersion product from competition. For the next simulation technology, we continue our EUV development and are on track to ship our first TWINSCAN NXE:3100s this year, and have now received our sixth order for this tool confirming the interest of now older, Semiconductor segments from DRAM and/or logic arena. We will ship the sixth pilot production tool in the next 18 months and are currently planning with all the industry leaders the 2012 production ramp for the new version of this machine called the NXE:3300. Orders will be taken already for these production UV tools by mid of this year. In summary, we expect this cycle to be sustained by the normal technology transition of the early adopters and the subsequent technology conversions by the second tier DRAM makers by the next Flash memory upgrade cycle anticipated for the second half of 2010, as well as the foundry structural capacity built under advanced nodes. In view of the technical requirements for immersion layer growth, which I mentioned is go as far as doubling for DRAM, we appear to be in no real risk of creating industry overcapacity between now and the end of 2011. Although we will remain, of course, cautious as to the overall state of the economy and its potential impact on overall semiconductor unit growth, which is the second driver of our gross behind the technology node transitions. So with this explanation, Peter and I will now be pleased to take your questions.

componenttext: It's Liberum Capital. You've said that you could see a Flash memory upgrade cycle in the second half, where Flash goes to 32 nanometer. Can you sort of quantify, on a relative basis, how big that can be versus the DRAM upgrade cycle that you're currently seeing to 40 nanometer? You think without a big  SSB-led boom, but you just get a significant Flash technology upgrade cycle. Can it come close to the levels of orders that the DRAM industry is placing? And a short follow-up, if I may, your capacity on the 1950 seems to be moving, at least your production is moving from nine to 11. What is your maximum capacity in that going to be in the second half of the year? And when will you be in a position or are you already in a position to satisfy customer requirements for any kind of rush orders on those tools at this point in time?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: So you could probably use a simple formula between DRAM and Flash. We think Flash is equal to 1/2 of DRAM, roughly, in numbers of immersion tools in units. Of course, you cannot have this every quarter. So some quarters may be higher and, et cetera. But we would expect the Flash 32 nanometer wave to start, as we said in Q3, to look like half of the big wave of 40 nanometer DRAM. So that is happening as we say at this moment. Regarding the capacity of immersion tool, as I said, I express myself in euro, a EUR 1.5 billion of capacity. That would be about 30-ish to 35-ish immersion tool per quarter. Plus the KrF, and et cetera, et cetera, of course. But your question was on immersion.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Odon de Laporte [CA Cheuvreux].

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: I have a question relating to gross margin. When I'm doing my math, I conclude that with sales of EUR 1 billion, Q2 gross margin could have been a little bit higher, maybe 50 basis points higher. So I was wondering whether it will be a clean, clean gross margin or maybe you will be penalized by any items, maybe in relations with the ramp up of NXT?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Yes, I think, clearly, we have guided a gross margin percentage of around 42% like we did around 40% for Q1. In Q1, we're 30 basis points higher. That is within the realm of, I'd say, the differences that can always happen during the quarter, 30 or 50 basis points difference, it could happen. I'm not saying that it will, but if you come 50 basis points up, that's pretty reasonable. But as you have seen also in the actuals, there's always somewhat of a difference between our guidance and what we actually come out with. But if so, it is within the margin of, you could call, error.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Timothy Arcuri [Citigroup].

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: First of all, Eric, you talked about the revenue capacity being roughly EUR 1.5 billion by year end. Does that suggest that there's a reset in lead time? So i.e., lead times now, what, nine to 12 months. And maybe that comes down pretty significantly later on this year. And if so, where does it come down to?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The lead time, by then, would be about three months. So in other terms, I don't say this to all our customers too much. But we can turn the orders within three months when we have reached the maximum capacity and have prepared the lenses. So in other terms, at the moment, we reach back a sort of a plateau work. We can offer customer very short lead time, turn around the time, which then makes the business much more stable for them where they put orders on the long term when they can do this and they can plan it. And they have x percent of the business, which can be done a very short lead time.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: So typically, whenever you see sort of a reset in lead times from such a long lead time to such a relatively short lead time, doesn't that usually drive a correction with bookings? Because there's, at least some portion of what's being booked today, that's happening because of the fact that your lead times are so long and people want to get in the queue. So I'm sort of curious as to why that kind of a reset in lead times would not drive a correction, maybe mild, but a correction nonetheless in bookings?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Well, no, I think you always have the same -- well, you have always the same behavior. Things that can be booked early like a new fab, as we discussed, or a new line is going to be booked early because people understand that the real lead time of those machines are within nine months -- six to nine months because you have to build up the lens, glass, et cetera, et cetera. So when they can do it, they will do it. So a very large part of our bookings will always be on that basis. Then you have a part of the bookings which are due to the fear factor. As you said, we need a slot. And you have a big part of our bookings, which is based on complete surprise, out of the blue. So depending on the year, the fear factor is higher than the blues. There's stuff coming from the blue, and sometimes the things coming out of the blue is higher than the fear factor. But this impact could be responsible for say, 20% to 25% of the fluctuation quarter-to-quarter of the bookings. But they are not, I would say, more significant than that.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: So just to make sure that I get that, so you're saying that roughly a quarter of your bookings right now are because of the fact that lead times are so long?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: You're putting words in my mouth. If we were, at this moment, I would say, because we have now accumulated two or three runs, we need to accumulate three quarters of high bookings. The question is not even real. The bookings are based on the fact that the customers now have realized that they need more capacity. It's driven not for double bookings. It's driven for definite -- I would put, in fact, all of our machines are expected, weighted for, they're all running at a bit above 100% capacity. So you can see in there, there's no paper tigers. This is, at this moment, highly, highly required. In fact, the first question was is the business going to be plus 15% or more? At this moment, everybody is thinking that it could be more than 15%. Therefore, every orders is for used. So I would not say at this moment that there is any luxury for what you just mentioned the possibility of saying, "S***, I have to double book because I'm not sure." That is not the case at this moment.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Also if you look at the presentation, 76% of the backlog is shippable over the next six months. So it's pretty tight. And it actually is more a proof that customers are not adhering to our standard lead times, which currently is not a very short lead time, but it is a long lead time; more for the leading edge products, closer to nine months than to the six months. So you have this management problem that we have that we have a lead time, a total lead time in the supply chain, which is in fact closer to nine months, and the order lead time that customers are granting us. And that is a game. That's a game between a customer and a supplier that is sometimes played very smartly by our customers, sometimes very smartly by ourselves.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Again, you may not really taken with the full seriousness the two messages we gave. The first message is that most of the industry semiconductors and beyond really are under product pressure. So there's clearly a volume pressure at this moment. And you're driving a lot of demand for that. And then second reason, second thing that I said, which is very, very important, in fact, is the numbers of layers on each of the chips are doubled in the immersion for DRAM, and probably 40% to 50% increase on Flash. And in 2011, these ratios, again, are increased; potentially not doubled, but not far from it. So at this moment, everybody, there's no rush to be overly smart about double booking. We are putting all the capacity necessary to, in fact, execute these ramp needs. The double booking opportunity, in fact, is impossible that, at this moment, because again, we are running everything at full capacity and our customers are doing the same.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Sandeep Deshpande.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: JPMorgan. Can I ask you regarding the orders in the current quarter itself? I mean, is it mainly still in the second quarter, the orders are still going to be very much in DRAM upgrades to immersion? And then the latter half of the year NAND? And secondly, regarding the NAND orders in the latter half of the year, are you talking about that you're already in discussion about new capacity NAND? Or are we just talking about the 32 nanometer shrink?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Peter, can you address that?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Yes, the orders in -- just to give you a breakdown of the bookings in Q1, just to refresh your memory, of the bookings that we have in Q1, it was about, I would say, 20% was Foundries/IDM. 55% was DRAM, about 10% was Flash, about 15% was what you call -- so called hybrids. So could be used for either/or, which we think is logically going to be DRAM. So that's the bookings split in the first quarter. We don't expect in the second quarter that it will be a big difference in that split. And we will probably see the first few bookings coming in for the Flash ramp, like you talked about the 30 nanometer ramp in the second half. But we don't expect a big change. So that's the first part of your question. And the second part of your question, I was looking at the data when you were asking the question. The second part was, Sandeep?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The second part I'm asking is in terms of the Flash bookings, are they only shrink-related that you expect in the second half? Or are you also in discussion about new fab and new capacity launches in Flash?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Definitely, there are some shells, as you know, in the Flash industry. And plus some of our customers will take the first tool shipments to start filling those first lines. So it's going to be a combination of the 30 nanometer shrink and the extension of capacity.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: But you expect a second half Flash capacity ramp, which would mean that you sell both immersion and lagging it, [indiscernible] adjusted from your ASPs, et cetera.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: That's correct. And it will not be in the front part of the second.  It will more be like the fourth quarter.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Atif Malik.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Morgan Stanley. Eric, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that we might not see an oversupply for a while. My question's on foundries. The foundries are spending, at least, the Tier 1 foundries had been spending quite aggressively since last year. And the capital intensity is about 40% level. And the last time we saw this high capital intensity was in 2004, which was followed by a correction. So as the yields that foundries 40 nanometer are low, like 40% to 50%. And you get 30% more incremental capacity, even 40 nanometer yields improve, I'm just curious how sustainable are the foundry bookings at level of from here onwards?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: First of all, the Foundry business that we have is only Tier 1. And I will not mention what name that means, but only Tier 1. Which means, I'll say the mechanics of this business is that the customers will force [ph] (32:02) a second source to the Tier 1. You are certain that you are going to have some duplicated capacity being put in the other Foundry businesses. These ones haven't started yet. So you know that this foundry buildup is going to happen anyway in parallel to the Tier 1.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: On top of that, I would like to add that you haven't compressed [ph] to 2004. 2004 was the 90 nanometer Logic ramp, which had 90 nanometer. We have many IDMs doing the same ramp. It's quite different than we have in 2010, where 45 nanometer Logic ramp is basically Foundry. So we had many IDMs at that same time, at that time, that were doing the same thing, and is now all concentrated. It's what you call consolidation. So I think it's difficult and also a bit dangerous to make that particular comparison.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: This is a follow-up on gross margin, Peter. If we just assume that revenues be at 1 billion level in the next few quarters and you have margins that are only 42% from software holistic contribution. How high can the margins go, if you assume revenue stayed flat at EUR 1 billion or do we need to see higher top line to get to the 45% target that you guys have talked about?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: I would say both. If you want to check, the 45% would need -- we've always had EUR 5 billion. We don't have EUR 5 billion today, but at EUR 5 billion in the future, which we hope is not going to be a very far future, that will be driven by the volume impact on the gross margin, but also by that time, the impact of the new, or what we call, the holistic litho products. So we are seeing shipments of the first of those products this year. They're going to add to the margin profile. But to get to the 45%, we've said that before, that's between EUR 1.2 billion and EUR 1.3 billion per quarter. That is a volume and a product mix issue. And we're well on the way, especially on the holistic lithography that Eric alluded to that in his speech. That we are being increasingly successful in selling those products. So that will add to the margin profile.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Simon Schafer.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Goldman Sachs. I had a question on -- just going back to this debate on lead time. When I look at your backlog today of the 58 in the margin systems, am I right in then saying that you can deliver all of those in 2010, and that's basically incorporated in your forecast? Just to understand the mix dynamics then from a pricing point of view going forward.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Yes, I think what you have on backlog is, what, 90% shippable in nine months. There is always a few strategic machines which have been designed by the customer, puts a bit longer than normal as I tried to explain at the beginning. Lead time is one thing, but when you know for sure that you need something at a given time because your walls are finished, you will say that's all. You can say this about, say 10%, I think is shippable later. But on the other hand, there are certain numbers of orders which are "virtual" at this moment. These consumers have told us they absolutely need the units but the paperwork is not finished. So that, in fact, has always represented a very large part of our business, which is why we do this forecast of bookings as well as the forecast of billings with usually some accuracy because we have so many virtual orders which are being discussed in terms of the spec, the timing and, in fact, sometime to price, et cetera, et cetera.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: So where we actually know that the likelihood of that happening is virtually 100%, but we don't have the paperwork. I think I'd like to correct, there's a feeling out there very often that there's a one-to-one correlation between our lead time, our production lead time and the lead time that our customers give us in terms of a sales order. That's not the case. I mean, we can have an internal lead time that takes us nine months to build a tool. And from day one, from that first day of the nine-month period, we can have a discussion with a customer for a particular shipment, and it can take two, three months before they finally give us the deal which is signed, sealed and delivered. Some customers are very good. They give us POs 12 months before. That's why we have POs for shipment in the first quarter 2011. There are also customers which are a bit tougher, we need to put a bit more effort in, in getting the POs on time. So don't assume that one-to-one correlation.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: I guess I'm just trying to go back to this earlier phrase that you used, I think, about the fear factor order, I think is what you called it. So how much of that do you think generally is out there now or if any at all?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: And as I said, I answered theoretically your question in case you are in a situation of constrained people, we have fear factor order virtually in this business at this moment. The need for machines and the placement of feature of the machine, I don't know how to express this better, but the placement of each of the machine in each of the places of each of the fabs are negotiated one by one. Remember, these are EUR 40 million each. You're not having fear factor order for the pleasure, especially that you have to take deliveries of them. As you know, our terms and conditions are pretty solid on that. So I apologize for having further misled people. At this moment, there is no issues of us, the older backlog we have and the virtual backlog that we have are absolutely required machines which will be immediately put in production to the maximum speed.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: And my second question would be, just if I look at your order book over the last nine months or so, as you said, NAND has been very dormant but maybe close to EUR 2 billion worth of orders being placed from the DRAM manufacturers for their shrink. I appreciate that NAND, of course, has a slightly different configuration of machine requirements in relation to wafer starts they're trying to get to. But I guess my question is, going forward, is the NAND upgrade cycle to the 3x worth a similar magnitude of this EUR 2 billion figure to what you've just seen for DRAM over the last nine months or so?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: I'm just checking one quick thing, the numbers of layers. Give me a second. No, DRAM is always going to be a much bigger business than Flash for two reasons. One, the numbers of layers of immersion required by the NXT technologies from 40 to 30 for instance, or 30 later to smaller or Flash. There's always a factor of about 50% more, 50% more immersion layers in DRAM. So that's one thing. And the second thing, if I'm not mistaken, the numbers of units of Flash is about half of the numbers of DRAM. So DRAM is a bigger business and it has more technology requirement.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: And to give you some color on the backlog, as you can see from our presentation, about 25% is Foundry and IDM. I'm going to give you the breakdown in the Memory segment. 45% is DRAM, 15% is Flash and 15% is what we call Hybrid, but that's largely, we think, is going to go to the DRAM side. So it's a pretty low number for Flash that we have in the backlog. And like Eric said, if you take -- it's about roughly 50% of the DRAM demand will finally end up being Flash demand. There's still some way to go.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Gunner Plagge.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: It's Nomura. If I look at the unit immersion backlog, it's now at this quarter almost 50-50 between XTs and NXTs. I mean, I was asking myself and looking 12 months out, who still will buy XTs in 12 months? Because, I mean, if I look at NAND, we have the Double Patterning development; in DRAM, overlay requirement. And if I understand correctly, in Logic, the overlay requirements are even worse than DRAM. So who's buying XTs in 12 months time? And if I look on it, the implied ASP for NXTs is about EUR 40 million. So is it totally unreasonable to model EUR 40 million immersion ASPs in 12 months' time?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: This is a very good question. In fact, we cannot answer fully that question, not we are hiding, but we're not 100% sure. It is true that if the customers want to have the appropriate target of a lith [ph] (42:06) for instance, they would convert 100% to NXT. However, we also know that there are some layers within the numbers of immersion layers which are less critical than others. So it may be that some customers would say, I want to optimize CapEx for one or two years, and they would have a mix. But it may be that a customer would say optimization for one or two years makes no sense and I prefer to buy the machine which have more extendibility. So to be clear, our history has been that the customers have always gone for extendability, which is why we've been, in some way so successful. But this time, we clearly offer the customer a choice between an XT or an NXT. Both machines will have about the same margin for us so it's not a big issue of what their choice is, but the customers may have then the choice between a cheaper version if they do not need to use a full performance.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: And having said that, I think to you question, it's almost time -- we do believe that our shipments will be predominantly NXT within 12 months. But like Eric said, the percentage of XT, there will be XT sales. And I was just -- will be, in the end, that's a bit difficult. So your assumption of a EUR 40 million flat ASP for immersion is, in that sense, a bit too optimistic.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Coming back to your famous model, I think you said before that in order to entertain a 50% bit growth for DRAM in 2011, you need about 250,000 additional wafer, and I think that was based on the assumption that 2010 is flat capacity, and I think what we see now in DRAM that indeed we see some capacity increases. So I mean, I'm just trying to understand, does it mean what you said before, you need 250,000 between end 2009 to 2011 to entertain basically a two-year 50% bit growth?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Do not remember fully all those numbers. I'm not trying to hide. . .

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: I think you said 250,000 is two to three fabs, so that might make it a little easier for you.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Wafer for starts [indiscernible] (44:30)

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: No, two to three fabs, with a fab of 100,000.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: In DRAM, all what I said was probably wrong, not because I was lying, it was because I was probably talking about 50 nanometer nodes. Now if you talk about 40 nanometer nodes, you have to multiply it by a factor which is a numbers of parties, as I just said, the numbers of layers. So what I can do is separately or frankly, and Craig could give those numbers to you, there is no secret. There is a need for much more immersion machine now on every new node. And there is another ratio for the 30 nanometer DRAM node, which is already being worked on. So all these nodes have a different response. So whatever I told you then was probably correct because it was based on an average mix of different nodes. And if I have to re-update those numbers for 2010 or for 2011, we can do it, there's no secret. But they are probably higher than what I ever said.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Adrien Bommelaer.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: It's Piper Jaffray. I had a question on EUV. I was wondering if you could give us some color on the progress done by the rest of the Semicap ecosystem to launch EUV. And I'm always a bit concerned that ASML is a little too far ahead of the others on this.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The first question about, are we too much ahead versus market needs, the answer is no. In fact, because EUV is considered a cheaper solution to a current problem, if you do Double Patterning immersion at the level of, say, 22 nanometer node or 18 nanometer node depending on which products you're talking about. EUV, at the current prices, is a cheap version. So if we succeeded, customers like it. And the proof is that we've got now six orders. And, say, by July, we probably will announce a certain numbers of orders for the new version called the 3300. So we are, time-wise with the current market need, okay. Are we ahead of the ecosystem? Good question. There are, I would say, four areas of concern. One is the light source, which is basically a supplier of ours. And at this moment, the issue with the light source is not so much if it works or not, if it's what is the power we're going to get out of that source. And at this moment, we have a minimum power which is already demonstrated, which already gets us into a more definitely breakeven of total cost-wise of EUV versus immersion. So every effort we do now an improvement, and granted we don't know how fast we can do that at this moment, but every effort is in the green territory. So we think that is under control. The second part or potential limiter would be the resist. And at this moment, resist at 10 millijoule per square inch, or 15 millijoule per square inch, depending on usage, is being proven. And you can see this resist I make at Albany, New York and at customers. The issue here would be line roughness, whether we can clean it up so that it allows perfection and good yield. So again, I don't think people will tell you that there is a showstopper. The next one is a mask, the blank mask in particular, and the writing. So here, again, most of the customers who are interested by this are big mask vendors themselves. And the fact that they buy our machines, we can think that it is a proof that they can find a way to build the mask and the blank. There are some issues, of course, of getting enough blanks at this moment or having the right -- the defect density on the blanks. But again, as I said, if they've had it or as a showstopper, anywhere that it's under their own control. And when you look at the amount of billions that we invest in R&D versus the poor amount of money that is required on that business, we don't think that is an issue. And the fourth issue is defect inspection on the mask, and that it is true. At this moment, the industry has not completely converged on an industrial solution. There are solutions, solutions like you test your defects not on the mask itself but on an exposure. That's possible, but that's not elegant.  And there are also ways of inspection based on non-EUV source, but on 193 source and you can see a significant amount of defect. Probably not everything you wanted to see, but -- et cetera. So this again could be considered, which I said today, as the area of least excitement. But those guys, as usual, react more when you are nearer to production because they are not a showstopper in the whole R&D and recipe management. They could become a showstopper when you want to get into full production. But full production is 2012 to 2013, so there is significant time to solve that.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: And also on top of that, Adrien, it is a fundamental issue in the sense that all these four things that Eric just mentioned, you can only really manage when you have this exposure tool. So you first have to have the tool before you can release all the other. So it is logical that if you don't have an exposure, that the exposure tool will be the first there and then the rest needs to follow because you cannot solve those problems if you don't have the tool.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Intel has actually made some fairly lukewarm comments regarding EUV in the last few months. And I was wondering, in terms of acceptance by the industry, who would look at this tool first for mass production?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Today, we are certain now that DRAM doesn't have easy workaround, and Logic, call it Logic aggressive, does not have easy solution. So for instance, when you are a Foundry business and you tried to do the maximum shrink on a given node, that is you give the maximum flexibility to your customers to shrink, there is no real solution. Flash could potentially get one generation more by cloud system, but that's it. Some other customers could decide to be less aggressive on some nodes and therefore, go around certain numbers of years. But I repeat my fundamental statement, what is important with EUV is that we reach a cost factor there. It's an economic decision. So every customer, including the person, the one you mentioned, will be moving into EUV at the moment ASML and their peers develop the right economic solution. So we're not dreaming here. And people would tell you at this moment they plan to convert in 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, et cetera. This moment is irrelevant if they do not know what economic equations we are giving. And if we are able to give an economic equation, which at the end of the day is cheaper than anything else, and you and I know there will be a jump into it. Now again, we do not feel highly concerned ourselves because if we cannot reach exactly the level of performance that we want, we can still do one or more years with our immersion machine and we would not be business impacted in some way. So we are doing this because we think it is necessary for the industry. We think that in any event past 2015 there are going to be some nodes where there is absolutely no choice. But between 2010, 2015, it's for us to define the economic equation that makes a transfer happen.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Pang.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010
componenttext: Caris & Company. First, on your capacity calculations that you used for the unit growth for semiconductors. Can you give us an idea of the type or the number of units that you're looking at for lithography tools?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2010

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Franki. So good morning, thank you for attending our second quarter 2010 result conference call. 
As usual, Peter and I would like to provide an overview and some commentary on the quarter. Peter will start with the review of the financial performance and we’ll add comment on the short term outlook. headline: ASML Holding NV, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric and welcome to everyone. As Eric mentioned I would like to take a moment to share observations on some of the events of last quarter as well as some details on our second quarter results. 
Our second quarter sales were EUR 1.69 billion, further 742 in the first quarter which was just above the range of our guidance. We shipped a total of 43 systems, 35 of which were new. Our new system ASP remained strong at EUR 25.6 million and it reflects the continued demand for leading edge lithography. Our net service and field option sales came in at EUR 146 million, driven by an increased demand for our holistic lithography and service products.
The company’s second quarter gross margin was 43% versus just over 40% in Q1. The gross margin improved due to volume-driven coverage of our fixed manufacturing cost, cost reductions and a better mix of higher margin products. We continued our immersionary re-product developments with an R&D spend of EUR 125 million in the second quarter. SG&A came in at EUR 42 million, both slightly higher than Q1 but as guided.
Higher sales and improved gross margin in Q2, operating income significantly improved to 27.4%, up from 18.5% in the first quarter and the second quarter’s a new high for the company. 
In the second quarter we generated EUR 193 million in operating cash flow and after deducting the CapEx spend and the dividend payment we added a EUR 100 million to our cash line ending just under EUR 1.2 billion at the end of the quarter.
Second quarter net bookings came in at 59 systems valued at close to EUR 1.2 billion. Net immersion bookings of 25 systems demonstrated again a continued focus on technology investments. But in addition, we also saw KrF bookings of 27 systems indicating an increased need for more non-critical systems in support of the leading edge production ramps which may then happened in the non-memory applications. Second quarter bookings moved our backlog 200 to just over 100 systems in total, valued at EUR 2.4 billion. We continue to be encouraged by the success of our immersion products demonstrated by the fact that there are 58 immersion systems in the backlog, the 38 of which are our newest immersion product, the TWINSCAN NXT 1950i. As for our outlook, we continue to ramp factory production capacity in order to meet the growing demand as indicated by our increasing backlog.
And our net of outlook indicates bookings in Q3 to be at around 1.3 billion. With this level of bookings and the ramp-up of our production capability, we now see our 2000 sales exceeding our previous peak of EUR 3.8 billion by about 10 to 15%. For the third quarter of 2010, we expect NXT sales to be about 1.1 billion. Gross margin for the second, for the third quarter is expected to be approximately 43%.
With R&D expenses rising EUR 237 million, which is basically to enhance the support of the EUV infrastructure. And SG&A rising to EUR 50 million supporting the growing level of sales anticipated through the balance of this and next year. However we have made sure that the increase of our cost structure remains flexible and have therefore managed 80% variability in our OpEx and manpower increase. With that commentary, I would like to turn it back over to Eric for more on our view of the coming few quarters. Eric?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter. So as you said, Q2 sales came a bit higher than planned and Q2 booking rose to nearly EUR 1.2 billion, a good number. We expect our bookings level to be higher in Q3, EUR 2 billion were good number. We expect our bookings level to be higher in Q3, also at about EUR 1.3 billion. With this, it is appropriate to ask ourself the question, if the current positive trend will continue or if we are seeing the first signs of macroeconomic slowdown of some sort.
At this point, we are confronted with request for capacity at a very brisk rate and we are discussing with customer the capacity increase plan which extend well into 2011. We therefore certainly see no weakening at all of the overall demand for lithography tools. This could be the result of an industry myopia, too much optimism or could create a potential for build up of excess capacity, although we do not think so in view of the drivers which are very strong behind the demand.
The first driver is a 2010 IC unit demand growth expected to be at about 15% versus 2009 putting the industry back on its historical growth curve. There is nothing extraordinary with this 15% level, achieved thanks to a healthy Chinese market and to somewhat average US and European economic environment. The other growth drivers are structural, the first driver is a standard technology transition driver which fuel this industry, which have been fueling this industry and which is currently indeed in play with an exceptional conversions of the ramp in the DRAM industry at 40-nanometer, in the Flash industry at 30-nanometer and also in the Logic industry at 40-nanometer. The 40-nanometer Logic ramp, volume ramp is now the transitioning from market prototyping or an early adopted phase, to a higher share of the total Logic business.
And at the same time, the more mature 65-nanometer is continuing its normal growth curve, that is the first structural driver. The second one is that the demand for new tools in the foundry and IBM segment is further increased due to several years of relative underinvestment and retirement of [obsolete] capacity by the IBM. The third structural driver has to do with technology transitions, which combined are resulting in an average doubling of the numbers of immersion layer exposures between 2009 and 2010. And this immersion layer exposure increase will continue well into 2011, as indicated in one of the slides that we have on our website, slide 21.
In view of these three structural drivers, and aware of the potential macroeconomic uncertainty however, we believe still that our 2010 revenues could exceed our previous 3.8 billion peak annual revenue by 10 to 15%, with no excess capacity being built, and that we expect this trend to continue into 2011.
On the technology front, as immersion processes are extended by the use of complex double patterning techniques, customers are accelerating the adoption of our holistic lithography suite of products in order to widen manufacturing process windows, and allowing faster startup of production of chips. This capability further increases our market leadership by making our systems even more efficient.
In addition our EUV program focus continues, as we speak, we are in the process of final integration testing of the first EUV pilot product in June, six of which we shipped within the next 12 months. Orders are being taken in this quarter by the way for delivery of production systems of EUV products and systems in 2012.
In summary, we expect lithography system remain to be sustained by one, the multiplicity of technology transition in all sectors, two significant wafer capacity addition in logic to make up for the low level of fast investment and re-target of similar capacity. And three, the emerging demand caused by increased critical layer processing associated with our current technology transitions. Although we remain cautious as to the overall set of the world economy and its impact on the overall semi-conductor universe, we remain fairly optimistic about lithography opportunity through out this year and the next. 
So with this summary, I think Peter and I will be ready to take your questions.
