headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and welcome to everyone. As Eric mentioned, I will take a moment to share some observations on the events of the last quarter as well as some details on our third quarter results.
Our third quarter sales came in close to EUR 1.2 billion, which is just above our guidance. We shipped a total of 51 systems, 40 of which were new. Sales were balanced between the Memory and Logic customers. Our new system, ASP, remains steady at around EUR 24 million, which reflects the continued strong demand for leading-edge lithography. 
Next is the leading-edge demand. We shipped a sizable number of die tools, reflecting additional wafer start capacity at our Memory and foundry customers. Our service and field options sales came in at EUR 149 million driven again by an increased demand for system performance enhancements and service products.
The company's third quarter gross margin was 43.6%, which was just above our guidance. The operating expense for the third quarter came in as guided, and we continued our immersion in EUV [extreme ultraviolet lithography] product developments with an R&D spend of EUR 137 million, and SG&A came in a bit lighter at EUR 48 million. With continued high sales and solid gross margins, net income came in at close to 23% of net sales in the third quarter. 
Net cash from operations was just about EUR 400 million, which was also fueled by customer prepayments, thereby growing our gross cash balance to between EUR 1.5 billion and EUR 1.6 billion. As mentioned before and in line with our stated policy, the company intends to distribute excess cash through payment of dividends and share buybacks. The size and timing of such distributions will be announced when it is appropriate. And as for our dividend, we will announce dividend proposal as part of our fourth quarter results.
The third quarter net bookings came in at 60 systems valued at EUR 1.3 billion. Immersion booking of 29 systems demonstrated a continued focus on technology investments, which was predominantly came from our Logic and DRAM [Dynamic Random Access Memory] customers. In addition, we saw KrF [krypton fluoride] bookings of 20 systems and 11 i-Line systems, indicating a continuing need for more noncritical systems in support of the leading-edge production ramps. Third quarter bookings moved our backlog to a total of 110 systems valued at EUR 2.7 billion. Our significant leadership position in immersion products is again demonstrated by the fact that there are now 63 immersion systems in the backlog, 48 of which are TWINSCAN NXT:1950i.
As for our outlook, demand for the TWINSCAN NXT immersion tools remains extremely strong, and we are challenged to produce enough systems in time to satisfy our customers' needs. We continue our focus on cycle-time reductions and introduction of more parallel workflows in order to meet the growing demand as indicated by our current backlog.
Our near-term demand outlook firmly indicates bookings in Q4 that will exceed the level that we saw in Q3. We see no signs of restrained demand for our tools as we believe that our customers, who clearly remain profitable, are in need of these tools to support their business strategies and related necessary cost reductions. With this level of bookings and the ramp-up of our production capability, it's also clear that we're beginning to see a potential for sales growth in 2010-11.
For fourth quarter of 2010, we expect net sales to be about EUR 1.3 billion with a gross margin for the fourth quarter is expected to be around 44%, with R&D expenses at EUR 140 million, which focuses on the second-generation EUV system deliveries and a third-generation EUV system development. SG&A is guided at EUR 50 million in continued support of the growing level of sales, which we anticipate throughout the balance of this year. As a reminder, this OpEx buildup remains largely flexible as we continue to use outsourcing and subcontracting to enable us to manage growth. 
With that, I would like to turn it back over to Eric for more on our views of the coming quarters. Eric?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter. So with a growing level of sales and bookings expected to continue, it is certainly appropriate to ask ourselves, what this current positive lithography trend means as it relates to the current negative sentiments regarding the macroeconomic environment. We indeed continue to receive a strong and continuous order flow for our systems in spite of some negative macroeconomic signals, like: the PC unit sales demand, which have been softening, in particular in the consumer area; some Memory pricing decreasing; some semiconductor inventory increasing a bit; and some indications of softer-than-expected short-term sales from some semiconductor vendors.
Well, the drivers for the strong demand for lithography equipment are the ones that we discussed before last quarter. They have not changed, and they do justify the current order flow. The first driver is a 2010 IC [integrated circuits] unit demand growth, which is expected to be about 15% 2010 versus 2009, a 58% bit growth of DRAM, 78% bit growth for NAND. This growth puts the industry back on to its historical cost curve, and there is nothing extraordinary with this level. And the analyst remain convinced that these numbers will happen in the short term.
The second driver is the need for next-generation tools to ensure a standard technology transition. That is not due to volume growth itself but to the fact that mix is changing. This driver has very high impact as it is sustained by a near doubling of the lithography critical layers. And in fact, we are seeing, in addition to these, an exceptional conversions of the ramp of three major industry segments: the DRAM segment, which ramps 40 nanometer; the Flash segments, ramping 30 nanometer; and the Logic segment, ramping 40 nanometer. And all of these happening at the same time, which is pretty rare.
The third driver has to do with the structural capacity development in the foundry world. First of all, 65-nanometer capacity is now catching up after several years of relative under investment and current retirement of obsolete capacity above 65 nanometer. And second, nearly all foundry players are now building new fabrication facilities for strategic capacity, which will deliver wafers well beyond 2011. So in other terms, this capacity, these new factories are not planned to produce any wafers short term. And therefore, will not be impacted by a macroeconomic situation.
The fourth driver is our growing market share, as our KrF and immersion systems offer unique performance in the market necessary for sustaining new node specifications. On this front, on the front of technology, we are seeing a growing need for tighter on-product overlay for immersion system but also for KrF. And therefore, a strong requirement for our products in the holistic lithography suite. These products extend the process windows and ensure a better process control.
Sales of the new NXT system are also accelerating. We will sell more NXTs, our new architecture in Q4 than the former generation XT system. These machines are capable of 175 wafer per hour while, at the same time, maintaining an overlay under 2.5 nanometer and offering a high level of capability for the customers for this transition, but for the next also.
Regarding the technology of the future beyond NXT, we are currently shipping the first of six NXE:3100, our second-generation extreme ultraviolet, that is EUV system, to a Memory semiconductor manufacturing site. This is a big deal. This machine has imaging capability close to 20 nanometer to productivity, which will reach 60 wafer per hour over time. To date, our EUV prototypes have only been operated at IMEC in Leuven, Belgium and in the nanotech laboratory in Albany, New York, where all major semiconductors producers have worked collaboratively in developing EUV lithography processes recipes. Five more NXE:3100 systems are planned to ship between now and mid-2011. 
But in parallel to that, ASML is developing a third-generation EUV tool and infrastructure, the NXE:3300, which imaging capability down to 17 nanometer and targeted at 125 wafer per hour for delivery already starting in 2012. And we have an exceptional success here also as we have agreed with customers on orders for eight of these NXE:3300 system and are in negotiation for additional orders, which we will close in the fourth quarter, that is, in this quarter.
In summary and somewhat redundantly from our previous calls, we expect lithography system demand to be sustained, thanks to structural drivers, not so much volume drivers. This includes a richer mix for new technology product in all sectors at the same time and the new foundry fabs providing 2012 wafer output and our market share growth. However, while we are focusing on delivery on this strong system demand, on this strong bookings, we will certainly remain cautious as to changing worldwide macroeconomics and its potential impact on overall semiconductor unit demand. 
With this, Peter and I would be pleased to take your questions.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The reasons why people like our products, like the NXT, is in fact twofold. One is, the NXT has precision, which is summarized by CD and overlay performance, which is unique in the market. And at this moment, this overlay and CD performance seems to be a fundamental for successful yield. So no matter what the throughput is, in fact, CD and overlay is a fundamental requirement. But on the other hand, don't misunderstand the point. In the fab, DRAM guy would be able to run the machine at, say, 92%, 95% of the time at maximum speed. In a Logic arena, the numbers would be more like 40% of the time at, say, 80% of the speed. But it is still a percentage of the capability of the machine. So if your machine is capable of a lot of wafers, even if you run it at 40% for a lot of reasons, logistics and technology, you still are making more money out of a machine that run fast than a machine that doesn't.

componenttext: Caris & Company. First, on your outlook for 2011, does the number of customers that you have changed significantly in your view?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: No. In fact, at this moment, as you know, we are doing business with every customer. So we will not have a new customer as I can guess, because I don't know if there is another one we can get to. In fact, maybe there's only one. But we will have probably more market share at two customers, which may mean that they will have a bigger size, bigger percentage of our business.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: And the follow-up is on the 3300. How many customers do you expect this year will order more than one tool?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: 3300? There will be two customers ordering two tools.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question is coming from Mr. Tom Dehudy. [Brandywine Global]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Brandywine Global. Can you give us some idea of what the price tag on the 3300 will be?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Yes. The price tag and the official price is EUR 65 million without options. Meaning, depending on the customer, you have a lot of options or you have less options.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question comes from Mr. Mehdi Hosseini. [Susquehanna Financial]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: From Susquehanna. Just as a follow-up, as you look into next year and given the capacity that you have brought on and I'm looking at the mix of full time and temporary employees you have, if we had a period of soft demand, air pocket, how flexible are you with the temporary employees? And I'm asking you this as I'm trying to better understand operating leverage or your flexibility in case there is some weakness or pocket of weakness, example, in next year?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: You have three variable aspect, which we have not changed, and it's still very open. One is our own salaries and staff is very variable. Our employees and management have a very high bonus level into their pay level. So if something goes wrong, we have a salary variability. The second bit is that we have a lot of contractors, not temporary workers. So contractors means we do subcontract R&D work. We do subcontract some activities, which we can stop from one day to the other if we wanted to, because, of course, strategically, sometimes we don't want to. So this would, if I take the example of R&D, we have a potential to reduce R&D budget by 20% to 30% if we play with contractors. And then, you've got, third, the temporary workers. I think we publicized the number, 2,000-ish people are on a temporary contracts. And these are contracts which allows us to reduce to zero in three months, but that doesn't mean we will do that. All these decisions are, I would say, strategic for us. If we have air pocket of one quarter, we probably would manage all that. If we have air pocket of a year, we probably will have to do it. And something in between will be a compromise.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: And to sum it up, the cost increase of our cost base 2010 as compared to 2009, that total cost increase, 75% of that increase is basically variable.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: And then just on the buyback and dividend, and when I look back to 2007, ASML and other equipment companies were relatively more aggressive on the buyback. And now, similar to companies from other industries and, obviously, executives and boards are more cautious, now if the capital industry is going to see another growth year next year, how come we haven't seen the kind of buyback that happened in 2007?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: I think it's a good question. But you'll need to realize in 2010, we came out of a extremely difficult year for the total industry. That did have an impact on existing cash balances. We saw the recovery this year. And in the case of ASML, for instance, we are just, let's say, at the upper end of our stated cash balance that we would like to keep for operational purposes. It takes a bit of time. And then especially in the capital goods industry, you first need to invest in a lot of working capital before that money comes back. So if you're asking why don't we see in the third quarter of 2010 a level of buybacks, well, it takes time to generate the cash.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: We haven't change our policy.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: That's the point. The policy has not changed. It means in 2011, you will see an acceleration of that cash generation. And I think in a year's time from now, you should ask the same question.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question comes from Mr. Francois Meunier. [Morgan Stanley]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: In terms of gross margins, I was wondering, your target of 45% is pretty close. Is it a linear trend in terms of revenues from here, or should we see it as different from a linear trend? And how should it behave above 45% gross margins?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: I think we answered that question a couple of questions ago in the sense that it's not a linear trend that, especially if you're approaching your target of 45%, like I -- just a brief repeat of what I said earlier. Gross margins are impacted by the absolute sales, because it gives you coverage of your fixed cost. It's the mix of products and especially when we have more application or holistic litho-type products with very high gross margins, it was in software. And it's also cost reductions when they are coming in, and cycle-time reductions basically learning curves. And those are relatively flexible, and those are not linear. But they do indicate a clear trend, and that's why I have made a comment about the ceiling of 44%. Now there is no ceiling on 44%.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: I'm now looking at the cash generation. It was pretty strong this quarter. I understand it's because of prepayments for EUV tools. So if I look at it, probably the cash will be very strong well, this half or this second half of 2010 and in 2011 as well and probably a bit weaker in terms of cash conversion in 2012 and 2013. So is this the reason why you're not starting the share buyback as of now, basically, because I think many shareholders are just expecting that to start now?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: I think I answered that question twice. We have a stated policy. And we have, and the stated policy says that within the bandwidth of 1 to 1.5, we feel comfortable to get keep that cash flow operational reasons. We're just starting to push outside that boundary. We do expect strong cash generation, which is not a surprise given our positive outlook on the rest of the year and 2011. So at the appropriate time, we will follow the local rules, which actually state that before you announce anything, we will make this public through a press release, and we'll give you the details of such a program.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: We didn't want to be opportunistic, but we haven't changed the policies. So if you are concerned about these, you have to realize that our policy is not to be opportunist but to do this through a very clear process of activities. And there shouldn't be no surprise to our shareholders about the actions on dividends and the actions on buybacks.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: But it was actually more a question on timing actually. Because, as I said, if you received the prepayments most of the cash from the EUV tools now rather than later, you do the share buyback now and maybe there is less room for share buyback in 2012, 2013?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Understood, but there is a process of doing buybacks. Some of us may be concerned about that it takes time to do this processes, but on the other hand, I think we have to do this in a responsible manner. So yes, you may have a point at if we had put a press release six months ago, saying we'll be above our target in due time and therefore we will prepare. It would have been smarter but, again, we're trying to avoid having some opportunistic approach to this. It's a bit complicated, but we haven't changed our appetite to execute exactly the policy. And at this moment, we have to execute it on the dividend side, as we committed to dividend. As you know, we committed to improve dividend as we go, and on the other side doing buyback when we are above our targets.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question is coming from Mr. Kai Korschelt. [Deutsche Bank]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: It's Deutsche Bank. First question was on DRAM. I think you commented before that you said most of the customers are seeing the current price weakness as temporary. I'm just wondering what if it was permanent sort of well into next year, and how would you expect that to impact maybe the order behavior or the plan for new capacity into the DRAM industry. And my second question that is, forget foundries, I mean, CapEx run rate in 2010 are at the highest level in several years. So I'm just wondering how sustainable is that sort of CapEx increase in 2011 that you were alluding to? Does that require further strong revenue growth for the foundries in 2011? Or could we see that even if there was sort of flattish revenue trajectory for this sector?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: So regarding the DRAM, the message I gave, which means that DRAM CapEx will be lower in 2011 than it is in 2010 is a percentage down and would be sustained by an assumption of about 50% bit rate. So you will know yourself if you understand that the market will go for 50% bit rate growth anywhere in 2011, then our plan is going to be sustained. If it goes lower than that, then you could see some reduction below our plans. However, this is compensated by the fact that the DRAM segment has gone through a much stronger technology transition behavior two years ago. And before, we used to have a transition every 18 months. Now since this year, we have a transition every year. So if you have a transition mid-next year again, we are in fact going to see the opposite happen. We're going to see an increase of CapEx. So in other terms, you've got now the driver, and you will yourself figure out exactly how that can impact us in the future. Regarding the total CapEx for 2010, let's recognize that for us, of course, it's going to be big number. We've guided 10% to 50% growth compared to the best year ever. But if you make this in relative terms versus our customers' total sales, you know the famous CapEx divided by sales of our customers, we're still in the 3% range or lower. I think, it's 2.5% to 3%, so we're not in the high number. We are clearly not in a history called high. So we could imagine that the CapEx number at this moment is definitely be sustainable at this 2.5% to 3% range. And I added to this that we have all seen the foundry segment and the Logic segment have really not bought anything for a fairly long periods, three years or four years. That it will take them 2010, '11 and potentially '12 to compensate for what they should have done in the first place before. So this compensation time is a good thing. Therefore, there is a scenario for ASML, which is the following. 2010 is good year, 2011 is going to be a better year, because of what we just said, and 2012 where you could start seeing a correction or one segment starting to sputter. And we will bring in EUV, which then is an enabler for major chip revolution, which we think can also get us to stabilize the whole thing. So we said six months ago that we maybe now on a trajectory of reducing the Lithography business being cycling, and I try again to articulate the fact that, so far, we confirm our point.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question is coming from Mr. Philip Scholte. [Rabobank]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Yes, it's Rabobank. As a follow-up maybe on that, can you remind us whether you expect to make a margin on your EUV systems comparable with what you are doing right now on your systems? And a slightly related question to that is on the roadmap of your EUV, it seems like in terms of resolution, you made pretty good progress with the machines. I'm looking at a presentation of last year, where the resolution is slightly lower, I would say. Can you confirm whether you have made some progress or have you overcome some issues there? Some more detail on that would be much appreciated.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Yes, so on the two machines, the 3100, the 3100 is a prototype, and we had a price target, which is a bit low at EUR 42 million. So these guys will not have a very high margin. It will not have the typical margin. It will be a bit under. But the machines at EUR 65 million will have the standard margin that we expect. Of course, in the first year it will be a bit lower than normal. And in the next year, it will become standard. And the following year, it will be a bit better, as we usually have. These are learning curve. On the resolution bit, yes, we are improving. And in fact, resolution as we grow on the 3100 and the 3300, the 3300, mainly, because of the smarter line of the lens and the smarter design of the illumination. So we've come up with pretty good ways of doing even better. And when we said 17 nanometer, we even think we can get to 15 nanometer, but that will have to be proven.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: And as a short follow-up, the fact that you are expecting NAND to, well, potentially double in 2011, is that also related to the increased speed of the NXT 1950?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: No. NAND, the business of NAND is probably going to be more than doubling from 2010. It's because in 2010, they haven't invested much. You heard Janardan give a feeling of it. He's not far from the truth, but it's a small number for NAND.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: But I'm actually referring to the solid-state drives [SSDs], whether that is becoming price competitive.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The solid-state drive is indeed a driver. But it is my understanding that, by far, the smartphone and then by second level, the iPad, are the major drivers for 2011. And the third part is really the disk drive. So you go first with smartphones, second, iPad and third, SSDs. But, again, I'm not a specialist who may want to [indiscernible].

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: The next question is coming from Sandeep Deshpande. [JPMorgan]

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: It's JPMorgan. I mean, just a quick question on the service revenues. I mean, your service revenues have been at a higher level for the last couple of quarters. I mean, do we expect them to be at these levels in the long term? And what has actually change? Has this to do with the Brion business?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Yes, I think we also indicated that, during our last quarter call, we used to say service revenues would be between EUR 100 million and EUR 125 million. I said last quarter, it will trend up to between EUR 125 million and EUR 150 million. Whereby in periods like we see today, clearly, it will be closer to the EUR 150 million level. Yes, there are some Brion and holistic litho products in there. But many of those products are actually sold as part of the system enhancement or options, which the customers order when they order the tool. So you will see what we call a factory options, which can be holistic litho products not showing up in that line. When it's a field upgrade, it will be field and service sales. So yes, it does have an impact, but the biggest impact is in the average selling price for our leading-edge tools.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Eric, one more question on the EUV. I mean, in the 3300, I mean, how many of those eight customers you've already signed up for 2012 are already in for the 3100 program? And also, with regard to the 3300, are you likely to sign up a lot more customers or are all mostly now signed up?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: No. So all of the, let me think -- on the 3100 players, two out of six have not signed up on the 3300. On the 3300, the eight that we have, eight orders, not eight customers, as I said two of them are two, we expect at the end of the year to have another maybe two or three more. And these will cover, I would say, every semiconductor, every guy of the top 10 maybe minus one. So in other terms, let me say it differently, I don't know if I'm clear, it is very obvious that all the Logic players have discovered that they cannot handle beyond 2015 without EUV. So all those Logic guys have clearly understood they cannot handle. They have to go. The DRAM guys have this -- it's the same situation, except it's not 2015, it's 2013 or 2014. So DRAM have to go. And the Flash have the chance to take EUV only if EUV is cost effective. And if it's not fully cost effective for them, they can push out for a bit of time. So the way I'm translating this is that the Logic guys and the DRAM guys are rushing to get the orders, and the Flash guys are the ones kind of waiting a bit to see when is it really strategic to get it.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: And you are saying that all the other collateral associated with the tools will be ready for production in 2012? This is mask inspection, the lasers. I mean, all the collateral will be available and ready.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext: Well, I would say now, you will have all bunch of my peers who on the phone is listen will scream at me and say I should not talk about these things, but I am. Either the mask inspection and resist infrastructure will be resolved because these are important issues but not fundamentally difficult issues, and players were waiting for us to show that, in fact, the machine was delivered. So at this moment, you have now a momentum, and level of technology issues to resolve is not an extreme situation. You just have to put a bit of money and go, so I would not be worried about that. The issue still remains for us and the three players of sources to prove what is the power that they can get out of an EUV laser, and that number is still the one to be proven. We are shipping our machine, so of course, we have already some run rate and stability. So we have a minimum. We're not yet at 60 wafer per hour, power-wise. That's not good enough. And within the period of now weeks and month, we will issue slowly but surely a press release that says, "Now we've reached this speed. Now we've reached this speed. Now we've reached this speed." So we feel that we have a bottom, which allows us to ship machines, but we are clearly not to the 60 wafers per hour, which would be considered comfortable.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttext:
Okay, ladies and gentlemen, I'm afraid we've gone over time for the call. If you were unable to get through and still have questions, please feel free to contact Investor Relations by email or telephone.
